nodes.text: The widespread use of constant elasticity of substitution (CES) functions in integrated assessment models (IAMs) misrepresents long-term technological energy transitions and creates an artifact of monotonically and exponentially increasing carbon prices that does not reflect technical substitutability or realistic technology costs

CES functions are share-preserving and imply that marginal rate of technical substitution depends on the ratio of inputs, yielding exponentially increasing required input of substitutes as substitution proceeds

When applied to fossil-to-renewable substitution, CES mathematical properties produce exponentially rising required renewable quantities and correspondingly exponential carbon price trajectories to force substitution
Historical technological and energy transitions follow S-curve (logistic, Gompertz, Bass) dynamics with evolving elasticity of substitution, not the constant elasticity implied by CES
IAMs that use CES or nested CES (e.g., GTEM-C, EPPA, GCAM, MERGE) produce similar high and increasing carbon price trajectories and limited substitution patterns consistent with CES artifacts

Mathematical derivation: CES production function implies MRTS_{R,F} = - (alpha/(1-alpha)) * (R/F)^{1+rho} and price elasticity of substitution epsilon_{F,R} = -1/(1+rho), producing decreasing marginal substitutability as R penetration grows

Illustrative CES example (stylized two-good energy model) shows that with realistic initial fossil share and typical elasticity values, reducing fossil share requires orders-of-magnitude increases in renewable quantity and carbon taxes rising up to hundreds or thousands times fossil unit cost
Including exogenous energy demand growth exacerbates CES-driven artifacts: required renewable quantities and carbon prices rise even faster under increasing output

Empirical literature documents consistent S-curve deployment and accelerating ease of substitution as penetration grows (examples: historical energy transitions, Nagy et al. 2013, Marchetti and Nakićenović 1979)

Observed IAM model outputs (cited studies) show carbon price knees late in century and very high end-century carbon prices (e.g., hundreds to thousands $/tCO2) and reliance on technologies present in initial model shares (CCS, biomass with CCS, nuclear)

Proposed modeling modification: use dynamically varying elasticity of substitution (linearly or exponentially decreasing rho) calibrated to expected technical profiles to reproduce S-curve dynamics within existing frameworks

Recommendation for a deeper shift: replace or augment price-centric, CES-based economic representations with physics-driven energy models that represent energy flows, storage, and technological learning to generate policy-relevant, physically plausible transition scenarios

Policy implications of CES-driven IAM artifacts include 'price diversion' (overreliance on carbon price instruments), 'sticker shock' (paralyzing high cost projections), and 'technological myopia' (favoring technologies already present in model shares)

Methodology used in paper: literature review of IAMs, analytical derivation of CES properties, stylized CES numerical examples, comparison to published IAM outputs, and proposal of dynamic-elasticity experiments

Final conclusion: continuing to use constant-elasticity formulations without accounting for dynamic elasticity or physical constraints will systematically overestimate mitigation costs and mislead energy policy; models should adopt dynamic elasticity or physics-based approaches and policymakers should set deployment targets beyond price signals
